Text saved: Around the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams represent feelings that are hidden from our normal, awake mind. Freud believed that if we understand what our dreams are telling us, we can understand these hidden feelings and the problems which they cause.

However, the other theory was the opposite, and it said that dreams are just a collection of random activity that happens in the brain while it organizes memories from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings, so we put them together into a story.

However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of activity without a pattern in the brain. This happens while the brain organizes memories from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these unplanned images and feelings, so we put them together into a story.
